content: The growth kinetics of HKUST-1 films was investigated by the time-dependent SEM analysis (, S6, and S7) and XRD measurements (Figure S8). Isolated crystals (∼750 nm) are formed in the first 3 min (a and S6), and they intergrow to form dense films after 40 min (b–d). With further prolonged reaction time, the average crystal domain sizes gradually increase from 2.5 (40 min) to 6.8 μm (240 min), and film thicknesses rise from 2.1 to 7.9 μm, correspondingly (e). The above results indicate the relative slow nucleation and fast growth in the crystallization process of HKUST-1 under current electrochemical synthesis conditions. Note that the reaction solution remains transparent during and after the electrochemical deposition (Figure S9), suggesting that the crystallization of HKUST-1 is substantially confined on the electrode surface under current experimental conditions. The porosity of HKUST-1 films deposited on FTO substrate was confirmed by krypton-adsorption measurements. As shown in f, the activated sample displays type I isotherms with a rapid increase in krypton uptake at low relative pressure (<0.01), indicating microporous structure. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area, which is expressed as the per film area per 100 nm film thickness, was calculated as 177 m2/m2/100 nm.
clean_text: The growth kinetics of HKUST-1 films was investigated by the time-dependent SEM analysis (, S6, and S7) and XRD measurements (Figure S8). Isolated crystals (~750 nm) are formed in the first 3 min (a and S6), and they intergrow to form dense films after 40 min (b-d). With further prolonged reaction time, the average crystal domain sizes gradually increase from 2.5 (40 min) to 6.8 μm (240 min), and film thicknesses rise from 2.1 to 7.9 μm, correspondingly (e). The above results indicate the relative slow nucleation and fast growth in the crystallization process of HKUST-1 under current electrochemical synthesis conditions. Note that the reaction solution remains transparent during and after the electrochemical deposition (Figure S9), suggesting that the crystallization of HKUST-1 is substantially confined on the electrode surface under current experimental conditions. The porosity of HKUST-1 films deposited on FTO substrate was confirmed by krypton-adsorption measurements. As shown in f, the activated sample displays type I isotherms with a rapid increase in krypton uptake at low relative pressure (<0.01), indicating microporous structure. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area, which is expressed as the per film area per 100 nm film thickness, was calculated as 177 m2/m2/100 nm.
